Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: They guide a patient on proper usage and potential side effects of a new prescription medication.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket just as I was explaining to Mrs. Lee how to take her new blood pressure medication. I glanced at the screen—Mom. I hadn’t called her all week, and she always worried if I didn’t check in by Sunday. Mrs. Lee looked anxious, her hands trembling as she clutched the prescription bag. I could see she needed reassurance, someone to patiently walk her through the instructions and side effects. But Mom’s message blinked insistently: “Are you okay? Haven’t heard from you.” Guilt twisted in my chest. I wanted to step away, call Mom, let her know I was fine, that I hadn’t forgotten her. But I also knew Mrs. Lee depended on me to be present, to answer her questions and ease her fears. Both needed me, right now, in different ways. I felt torn, the weight of their expectations pressing in from both sides, and I stood there, phone in hand, heart pulled in two directions, unsure which role to answer first.
